title: The controversial origins of the Encyclopedia - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: Who commissioned Denis Diderot to adapt the English cyclopedia for French subscribers in 1745?

options.label: A
options.text: André le Breton

options.label: B
options.text: Jean le Rond d'Alembert

options.label: C
options.text: Louis de Jaucourt

options.label: D
options.text: Voltaire

multiple-choice.question: What comprehensive publication did Denis Diderot and Jean le Rond d'Alembert produce, covering all knowledge?

options.label: A
options.text: Encyclopedia or Rational Dictionary of the Arts, Sciences, and Crafts

options.label: B
options.text: Classification of Knowledge

options.label: C
options.text: Universal Dictionary of Arts and Sciences

options.label: D
options.text: The French Enlightenment Dictionary

multiple-choice.question: What three-part system, adapted from Francis Bacon's "Classification of Knowledge," did Denis Diderot use to organize the encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: Memory, Reason, and Imagination

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding, Experience, and Perception

options.label: C
options.text: Knowledge, Insight, and Intuition

options.label: D
options.text: Analysis, Synthesis, and Evaluation

multiple-choice.question: Who wrote much of the music section in the encyclopedia in three months without being reimbursed for copy fees?

options.label: A
options.text: Jean Jacques Rousseau

options.label: B
options.text: Denis Diderot

options.label: C
options.text: Jean le Rond d'Alembert

options.label: D
options.text: Louis de Jaucourt

multiple-choice.question: What was the title of Jean le Rond d'Alembert's famous preliminary discourse that championed independent investigative reasoning as the path to progress?

options.label: A
options.text: Preliminary Discourse

options.label: B
options.text: The Social Contract

options.label: C
options.text: Discourse on Reason and Progress

options.label: D
options.text: An Essay on Enlightenment

multiple-choice.question: Which prominent philosopher contributed entries to the encyclopedia, including history, elegance, and fire?

options.label: A
options.text: Voltaire

options.label: B
options.text: Denis Diderot

options.label: C
options.text: Jean le Rond d'Alembert

options.label: D
options.text: Immanuel Kant

multiple-choice.question: What was the consequence of publishing the first two volumes of the encyclopedia?

options.label: A
options.text: It was widely acclaimed by the French monarchy and clergy

options.label: B
options.text: It was banned by King Louis XV and condemned by Pope Clement XIII

options.label: C
options.text: It was well-received by the French Regime but criticized by the public

options.label: D
options.text: It was ignored by the public and the authorities

multiple-choice.question: Who helped Denis Diderot by tipping him off to impending raids and hiding his papers at his father's house?

options.label: A
options.text: Madame de Pompadour

options.label: B
options.text: Malesherbes

options.label: C
options.text: Jean le Rond d'Alembert

options.label: D
options.text: Louis de Jaucourt

multiple-choice.question: Why did Pope Clement XIII order the encyclopedia to be burned?

options.label: A
options.text: It was considered "dangerous" and "reprehensible"

options.label: B
options.text: It was written in French

options.label: C
options.text: It was written in the most seductive style

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: In what year did the uncensored pages of the encyclopedia reappear in Russia?

title: The science of skin color - Angela Koine Flynn

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the difference in skin color among individuals?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetic variation in eye color

options.label: B
options.text: Environmental factors such as climate and diet

options.label: C
options.text: Random chance and individual mutations

options.label: D
options.text: Evolutionary adaptation to the Sun's UV radiation

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the pigment responsible for skin and hair color in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: Rhodopsin

options.label: B
options.text: Eumelanin

options.label: C
options.text: Carotene

options.label: D
options.text: Melanin

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of melanin in the skin?

options.label: A
options.text: To absorb light and produce vitamin D

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate body temperature and blood pressure

options.label: C
options.text: To produce new skin cells and collagen

options.label: D
options.text: To shield cells from damage caused by UV light

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential result of severe damage to skin cells caused by prolonged exposure to UV light?

options.label: A
options.text: Vitamin D deficiency and fatigue

options.label: B
options.text: Rickets and osteoporosis

options.label: C
options.text: Skin burn and premature aging

options.label: D
options.text: Melanoma, a type of skin cancer

multiple-choice.question: How did early humans cope with the damaging effects of UV light before the existence of sunscreen?

options.label: A
options.text: By using protective clothing and headgear

options.label: B
options.text: By staying indoors during peak sun hours

options.label: C
options.text: By applying plant extracts and natural oils

options.label: D
options.text: By producing melanin, their own natural sunscreen

multiple-choice.question: What determines an individual's level of protection from the sun's UV radiation?

options.label: A
options.text: Skin color and tone

options.label: B
options.text: Age and sex

options.label: C
options.text: Genetics and family history

options.label: D
options.text: Type and amount of melanin in the skin

multiple-choice.question: What is a beneficial effect of UV light on the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: Producing melanin and skin pigmentation

options.label: B
options.text: Shielding cells from damage and inflammation

options.label: C
options.text: Regulating body temperature and circulation

options.label: D
options.text: Strengthening bones and absorbing vital minerals through vitamin D production

multiple-choice.question: What is a condition that can result from a lack of vitamin D in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Melanoma, a type of skin cancer

options.label: B
options.text: Skin conditions such as acne and eczema

options.label: C
options.text: Fatigue, weakness, and muscle pain

options.label: D
options.text: Rickets, a disease characterized by softening of the bones

multiple-choice.question: Why did some humans living in northern regions develop lighter skin over time?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they were exposed to more intense sunlight

options.label: B
options.text: Because they had a higher melanin production threshold

options.label: C
options.text: Because they had a genetic mutation that reduced melanin production

options.label: D
options.text: Because they produced less melanin, allowing for better absorption of UV light and vitamin D production

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the diversity of skin colors among humans?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetic variation and random chance

options.label: B
options.text: Environmental factors such as climate and diet

options.label: C
options.text: Cultural and social influences

options.label: D
options.text: Evolutionary adaptation to the Sun's UV radiation and varying levels of melanin production

title: How to speak so that people want to listen

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary focus of the speaker's talk?

options.label: A
options.text: Strategies for effective public speaking

options.label: B
options.text: The power of speaking to create positive change in the world

options.label: C
options.text: Effective communication in personal relationships

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of noise on our environment

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what are the "seven deadly sins of speaking" that hinder effective communication?

options.label: A
options.text: Gossip, judging, negativity, complaining, excuses, embroidery, and dogmatism

options.label: B
options.text: Gossip, negativity, complaining, excuses, dogmatism, and lying

options.label: C
options.text: Gossip, negativity, complaining, excuses, and dogmatism

options.label: D
options.text: Gossip, negativity, complaining, excuses, and embroidery

multiple-choice.question: What are the four essential foundations that the speaker suggests for powerful and effective speech?

options.label: A
options.text: Honesty, authenticity, integrity, and love

options.label: B
options.text: Honesty, authenticity, and integrity

options.label: C
options.text: Honesty, authenticity, and love

options.label: D
options.text: Honesty, integrity, and respect

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker define the word "hail" in the context of powerful speech?

options.label: A
options.text: To speak or shout loudly

options.label: B
options.text: To listen carefully

options.label: C
options.text: To greet or acclaim enthusiastically

options.label: D
options.text: To be silent

multiple-choice.question: What term does the speaker use to describe the way a person's voice feels to the listener?

options.label: A
options.text: Register

options.label: B
options.text: Timbre

options.label: C
options.text: Prosody

options.label: D
options.text: Tone

multiple-choice.question: What term does the speaker use to describe the sing-song or meta-language used to impart meaning in conversation?

options.label: A
options.text: Register

options.label: B
options.text: Timbre

options.label: C
options.text: Prosody

options.label: D
options.text: Inflection

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the term for imposing one's sound on others carelessly and inconsiderately?

options.label: A
options.text: Sodcasting

options.label: B
options.text: Noise pollution

options.label: C
options.text: Sound fatigue

options.label: D
options.text: Audio overload

multiple-choice.question: What are the six vocal warm-up exercises that the speaker recommends for effective speaking?

options.label: A
options.text: Arms up, deep breath in, and sigh out, Ba, Ba, Ba, brrrrrrrrrr, la, la, la, and Rrrrrrr

options.label: B
options.text: Arms up, deep breath in, sigh out, Ba, Ba, Ba, brrrrrrrrrr, la, la, la, and weeeaawww

options.label: C
options.text: Arms up, deep breath in, sigh out, Ba, Ba, Ba, brrrrrrrrrr, la, la, la, Rrrrrrr, and weeeaawww

options.label: D
options.text: Arms up, deep breath in, sigh out, brrrrrrrrrr, la, la, la, Rrrrrrr, and weeeaawww

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what idea is worth spreading?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of listening in conversation

options.label: B
options.text: The power of speaking to make change in the world

options.label: C
options.text: A world where understanding would be the norm

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of noise on our environment

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what would be the result of creating sound consciously, consuming sound consciously, and designing environments consciously for sound?

options.label: A
options.text: A world with more noise pollution

options.label: B
options.text: A world with less effective communication

options.label: C
options.text: A world that sounds beautiful and fosters understanding

options.label: D
options.text: A world with less understanding

title: Every kid needs a champion - Rita Pierson

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what are some common factors that contribute to kids dropping out of school?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of parental support, academic pressure, and bullying

options.label: B
options.text: Negative peer influences, lack of extracurricular activities, and poor school infrastructure

options.label: C
options.text: Poverty, low attendance, and negative peer influences

options.label: D
options.text: Poor school infrastructure, lack of resources, and academic pressure

multiple-choice.question: Who said that "no significant learning can occur without a significant relationship"?

options.label: A
options.text: George Washington Carver

options.label: B
options.text: James Comer

options.label: C
options.text: Stephen Covey

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the speaker's strategy of telling students that they were chosen to be in her class because she is the best teacher and they are the best students?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a sense of competition among students

options.label: B
options.text: To boost students' self-esteem and make them feel valued and confident

options.label: C
options.text: To emphasize the importance of academic achievement

options.label: D
options.text: To encourage students to work together to achieve a common goal

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker approach giving feedback to students who perform poorly on a quiz?

options.label: A
options.text: She focuses on the negative aspects of their performance

options.label: B
options.text: She gives them a positive score and a smiley face to encourage them and emphasize progress

options.label: C
options.text: She only gives feedback on their strengths

options.label: D
options.text: She provides detailed, constructive feedback on their weaknesses

multiple-choice.question: What approach does the speaker's mother take to teaching and helping her students?

options.label: A
options.text: She focuses on academic achievement only

options.label: B
options.text: She takes a holistic approach, providing emotional, material, and academic support

options.label: C
options.text: She only provides material support to her students

options.label: D
options.text: She emphasizes the importance of discipline in the classroom

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why are kids who are struggling with personal hygiene hard to teach?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not motivated

options.label: B
options.text: They are not interested in learning

options.label: C
options.text: They may face ridicule and cruelty from their peers, making it difficult for them to focus and learn

options.label: D
options.text: They lack access to educational resources

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to educators about the nature of teaching and learning?

options.label: A
options.text: That teaching is a thankless job

options.label: B
options.text: That educators should focus on policy and not on students

options.label: C
options.text: That teaching and learning should be joyful, empowering, and relationship-driven experiences

options.label: D
options.text: That educators should prioritize academic achievement above all else

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is a key characteristic of a child who has a champion?

options.label: A
options.text: They are afraid to take risks

options.label: B
options.text: They are confident, willing to take risks, and believe in their abilities

options.label: C
options.text: They are not interested in learning

options.label: D
options.text: They lack confidence in their abilities

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to educators about their role in the lives of their students?

options.label: A
options.text: That they should only focus on academics

options.label: B
options.text: That they should be champions for their students, providing emotional support, advocacy, and believing in their potential

options.label: C
options.text: That they should only provide material support to their students

options.label: D
options.text: That they should maintain a professional distance from their students

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main legacy that educators can leave behind?

options.label: A
options.text: A legacy of academic achievement

options.label: B
options.text: A legacy of positive relationships, lasting impact on students' lives, and empowering them to succeed

options.label: C
options.text: A legacy of material wealth

options.label: D
options.text: A legacy of policy changes

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of chlorophyll in plant cells during photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: To synthesize organic compounds from carbon dioxide

options.label: B
options.text: To release oxygen into the atmosphere

options.label: C
options.text: To convert sunlight into chemical energy

options.label: D
options.text: To absorb and store water

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is NOT a product of photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: Glucose

options.label: C
options.text: ATP

options.label: D
options.text: Carbon dioxide

multiple-choice.question: What process allows plants to release water vapor into the air through their leaves?

options.label: A
options.text: Respiration

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Transpiration

options.label: D
options.text: Evaporation from soil

multiple-choice.question: How will a plant's rate of photosynthesis be affected if it is placed in a dark environment?

options.label: A
options.text: It will increase

options.label: B
options.text: It will decrease but not cease

options.label: C
options.text: It will remain the same

options.label: D
options.text: It will cease to occur

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following organisms is capable of undergoing photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Human

options.label: B
options.text: Fungus

options.label: C
options.text: Algae

options.label: D
options.text: Most animals

multiple-choice.question: What type of energy is absorbed by chlorophyll during the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemical energy

options.label: B
options.text: Thermal energy

options.label: C
options.text: Kinetic energy

options.label: D
options.text: Light energy

multiple-choice.question: How will a plant's growth rate be affected if it is grown in a controlled environment with limited light?

options.label: A
options.text: It will increase

options.label: B
options.text: It will likely decrease

options.label: C
options.text: It will remain the same

options.label: D
options.text: It will become dormant immediately

multiple-choice.question: What process do plants use to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose using energy from sunlight?

options.label: A
options.text: Respiration

options.label: B
options.text: Photosynthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Transpiration

options.label: D
options.text: Fermentation

multiple-choice.question: What is a direct product of the light-dependent reactions in photosynthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: Glucose

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen

options.label: C
options.text: ATP and NADPH

options.label: D
options.text: Amino acids

multiple-choice.question: How will a plant's rate of photosynthesis be affected if it is grown in a soil with low nutrient levels?

options.label: A
options.text: It will increase

options.label: B
options.text: It will likely decrease

options.label: C
options.text: It will remain the same

options.label: D
options.text: It will become unstable

title: How to make your writing funnier - Cheri Steinkellner

multiple-choice.question: How can you discover humor in everyday life?

options.label: A
options.text: By paying attention to ordinary, often overlooked details and finding the unexpected in them.

options.label: B
options.text: By focusing on complex, abstract concepts that are difficult to relate to.

options.label: C
options.text: By relying on overused jokes and clichés that have lost their comedic value.

options.label: D
options.text: By observing only extraordinary events that are rare and unusual.

multiple-choice.question: What are the fundamental elements of great storytelling, including comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Character development and plot twists.

options.label: B
options.text: Who, what, when, where, why, and how.

options.label: C
options.text: What, when, and why.

options.label: D
options.text: Theme, tone, and setting.

multiple-choice.question: According to the Commedia rule, how can you create comedic characters?

options.label: A
options.text: By exaggerating their flaws and imperfections to make them more relatable and humorous.

options.label: B
options.text: By making them perfect and flawless, which can lead to uninteresting characters.

options.label: C
options.text: By giving them generic traits without any distinct characteristics, making them unmemorable.

options.label: D
options.text: By making them overly complex and hard to relate to, which can confuse the audience.

multiple-choice.question: According to Aristotle, what is the key to humor?

options.label: A
options.text: Emotional connection and empathy alone.

options.label: B
options.text: Anticipation and predictability, which can make humor feel stale.

options.label: C
options.text: Expectation and familiarity, which can lead to a sense of comfort rather than humor.

options.label: D
options.text: Surprise and unexpected twists that subvert our expectations.

multiple-choice.question: What theory of humor states that we laugh at things that seem out of place or run up against our expectations?

options.label: A
options.text: Relief theory.

options.label: B
options.text: Incongruity theory.

options.label: C
options.text: Anticipation theory.

options.label: D
options.text: Superiority theory.

multiple-choice.question: What is a fun way to discover incongruities in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating a mind map to visualize connections and explore new ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: Brainstorming alone without any tools or references to limit your creativity.

options.label: C
options.text: Reading books on comedy theory and history without applying the knowledge in your writing.

options.label: D
options.text: Conducting surveys to gather opinions on what is funny.

multiple-choice.question: What is another effective way to generate comedic material?

options.label: A
options.text: Shifting from observation to imagination and exploring "what if" scenarios to create new and interesting ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: Sticking to reality and facts without adding any creative twist, which can lead to stale humor.

options.label: C
options.text: Relying on personal experiences only without exaggeration or creative liberties, which can limit your comedic range.

options.label: D
options.text: Using sarcasm and irony as the only means of humor.

multiple-choice.question: What is the rule of three, or zig zig zag, in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Setting up an expected pattern and then subverting it for comedic effect to create surprise and humor.

options.label: B
options.text: Setting up a random pattern and sticking to it without any twist, which can lead to confusion.

options.label: C
options.text: Avoiding using patterns altogether, which can make your humor feel disjointed.

options.label: D
options.text: Using a consistent and predictable pattern throughout.

multiple-choice.question: What is the punchline rule in comedy writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Placing the punchline at the beginning of the joke, which can make the joke feel stale.

options.label: B
options.text: Placing the punchline in the middle of the joke without any buildup, which can make the joke feel confusing.

options.label: C
options.text: Avoiding punchlines and using only setup.

options.label: D
options.text: Placing the punchline at the end of the joke for maximum impact and surprise.

multiple-choice.question: What is the most important rule of writing humorously, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Following a set of strict guidelines and formulas without any creativity or originality.

options.label: B
options.text: Sticking to a straightforward approach without taking risks or trying new things.

options.label: C
options.text: Focusing solely on pleasing everyone's sense of humor, which can be impossible.

options.label: D
options.text: Having fun and being open to experimentation and creativity to create unique and original humor.

title: The immortal cells of Henrietta Lacks - Robin Bulleri

multiple-choice.question: Who was the Johns Hopkins scientist that received a sample of a strange-looking tumor, leading to the discovery of the first immortal human cell line?

options.label: A
options.text: Jonas Salk

options.label: B
options.text: George Gey

options.label: C
options.text: A researcher at a different university

options.label: D
options.text: Henrietta Lacks' primary care physician

multiple-choice.question: From whom were the HeLa cells originally harvested?

options.label: A
options.text: Henrietta Lacks

options.label: B
options.text: A patient with breast cancer

options.label: C
options.text: A patient with ovarian cancer

options.label: D
options.text: A patient with a different type of cancer

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which normal human cells self-destruct after dividing about 50 times, preventing the propagation of genetic errors?

options.label: A
options.text: Apoptosis

options.label: B
options.text: Mitosis

options.label: C
options.text: Cellular senescence

options.label: D
options.text: Cell differentiation

multiple-choice.question: What enzyme, first discovered in HeLa cells, helps cancer cells evade destruction by repairing their DNA?

options.label: A
options.text: Telomerase

options.label: B
options.text: DNA polymerase

options.label: C
options.text: Topoisomerase

options.label: D
options.text: Helicase

multiple-choice.question: What virus was discovered to cause cervical cancer, thanks in part to research using HeLa cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Human Papillomavirus (HPV)

options.label: B
options.text: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)

options.label: C
options.text: Ebola virus

options.label: D
options.text: Hepatitis B virus

multiple-choice.question: Who developed the inactivated poliovirus vaccine using HeLa cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Jonas Salk

options.label: B
options.text: George Gey

options.label: C
options.text: Edward Jenner

options.label: D
options.text: Louis Pasteur

multiple-choice.question: What was the estimated number of HeLa cells produced per week in the world's first cell production facility?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 trillion

options.label: B
options.text: 6 trillion

options.label: C
options.text: 10 trillion

options.label: D
options.text: 50 trillion

multiple-choice.question: How many chromosomes are typically found in a normal human cell?
What was discovered using HeLa cells that makes chromosomes visible?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of virus

options.label: B
options.text: A new species of bacteria

options.label: C
options.text: A chemical that stains chromosomes

options.label: D
options.text: A new type of cell division

multiple-choice.question: What is notable about the way HeLa cells can travel and interact with other cells?

options.label: A
options.text: They are unable to invade other cell cultures.

options.label: B
options.text: They can only travel through direct contact.

options.label: C
options.text: They can travel on almost any surface and invade cultures of other cells.

options.label: D
options.text: They require a specific medium to interact with other cells.

title: Zika Virus Spreading in Most of the Americas

options.label: B
options.text: Harper Lee

options.label: C
options.text: Jane Austen

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Assonance

options.label: C
options.text: Consonance

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Stream-of-consciousness

options.label: B
options.text: Imagery

options.label: C
options.text: Symbolism

options.label: D
options.text: Free verse

options.label: A
options.text: Holden Caulfield

options.label: B
options.text: Huckleberry Finn

options.label: C
options.text: Tom Sawyer

options.label: D
options.text: Nick Carraway

multiple-choice.question: Which literary device involves the repetition of vowel sounds in closely connected words to create a harmonious effect?

options.label: A
options.text: Alliteration

options.label: B
options.text: Assonance

options.label: C
options.text: Consonance

options.label: D
options.text: Enjambment

multiple-choice.question: Who is the American poet behind the poem "The Road Not Taken", known for exploring themes such as isolation in rural New England settings?

options.label: A
options.text: Robert Frost

options.label: B
options.text: Edgar Allan Poe

options.label: C
options.text: Emily Dickinson

options.label: D
options.text: Walt Whitman

multiple-choice.question: What literary device involves the use of words that phonetically imitate the sounds they describe?

options.label: A
options.text: Onomatopoeia

options.label: B
options.text: Alliteration

options.label: C
options.text: Assonance

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: #TEDEdChat: A Math Class Makeover | Dan Meyer |

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's primary concern about the way math is taught in the US?

options.label: A
options.text: Students are not learning enough math concepts.

options.label: B
options.text: Students are not retaining math concepts due to a lack of patient problem-solving skills.

options.label: C
options.text: Teachers are not teaching math concepts effectively due to inadequate training.

options.label: D
options.text: The math curriculum is too easy and does not challenge students.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main issue with the way math textbooks are written?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too easy to understand and lack challenging problems.

options.label: B
options.text: They do not provide enough examples and practice problems for students to master concepts.

options.label: C
options.text: They present problems in a way that does not allow students to develop patient problem-solving skills.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not aligned with the math curriculum and standards.

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker's approach to teaching math differ from traditional teaching methods?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker uses a traditional approach, presenting problems and expecting students to solve them.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker involves students in the formulation of problems and encourages them to develop patient problem-solving skills.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker uses a project-based approach, where students work on real-world projects to learn math concepts.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker uses a technology-based approach, relying on online resources and software to teach math.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal in teaching math, and how does it relate to patient problem-solving skills?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker's goal is to teach students a set of math concepts and formulas to memorize.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker's goal is to help students develop patient problem-solving skills, enabling them to apply math concepts to real-world situations.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker's goal is to prepare students for standardized tests and assessments.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker's goal is to teach students how to use technology to solve math problems.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the value of using multimedia resources in teaching math?

options.label: A
options.text: They provide a more engaging and interactive learning experience for students.

options.label: B
options.text: They allow teachers to present complex math concepts in a more visual and accessible way.

options.label: C
options.text: They enable students to work independently and at their own pace.

options.label: D
options.text: They bring the real world into the classroom in high resolution and full color, making math more relevant and interesting.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice to teachers who want to create a more engaging and effective math curriculum?

options.label: A
options.text: They should use technology-based resources and software to teach math.

options.label: B
options.text: They should focus on presenting math concepts and formulas in a clear and concise way.

options.label: C
options.text: They should involve students in the formulation of problems and encourage them to develop patient problem-solving skills.

options.label: D
options.text: They should use a combination of traditional teaching methods and multimedia resources.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of using open licenses to distribute educational resources?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows teachers to customize and adapt resources to meet the needs of their students.

options.label: B
options.text: It enables teachers to share resources with other educators and collaborate on curriculum development.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides access to high-quality educational resources at a low cost.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's conclusion about the demand for effective math education?

options.label: A
options.text: There is a lack of interest in math education among students and educators.

options.label: B
options.text: There is a growing demand for effective math education, and educators are hungry for resources and support.

options.label: C
options.text: Math education is not necessary for success in the modern world.

options.label: D
options.text: Math education is only necessary for students who plan to pursue careers in math or science.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why are patient problem-solving skills important in math education?

options.label: A
options.text: They enable students to apply math concepts to real-world situations and think critically.

options.label: B
options.text: They help students to develop analytical skills, but are not essential for math education.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not necessary for effective math education and can be skipped.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only necessary for students who plan to pursue careers in math or science.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to educators and policymakers?

options.label: A
options.text: They should focus on implementing traditional teaching methods and textbooks.

options.label: B
options.text: They should prioritize the development of patient problem-solving skills in math education.

options.label: C
options.text: They should rely on technology-based resources and software to teach math.

options.label: D
options.text: They should insist on better math curriculum that promotes patient problem-solving skills and prepares students for the real world.

title: Can you solve the temple riddle? - Dennis E. Shasha

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge faced by the group of students in the ancient temple?

options.label: A
options.text: Finding the exit before the temple collapses

options.label: B
options.text: Avoiding the secret traps

options.label: C
options.text: Determining which students are cursed by the temple's spirits and finding the correct path

options.text: Deciphering the inscriptions on the walls to unlock a door

options.label: B
options.text: They will be led to their doom through deception by occasionally lying

options.label: C
options.text: They will be given a map to the exit

options.label: D
options.text: They will be granted a magical power

options.label: C
options.text: It means that the group is close to the exit

options.text: It means that the group is still lost

options.label: D
options.text: The group is still lost

options.label: A
options.text: It means that the group is doomed

options.label: B
options.text: It means that the group can safely trust the majority in both trios

options.label: C
options.text: It means that the group is lost

options.label: D
options.text: It means that the group must start over

options.text: Because the possessed students might always lie

options.text: The group is still lost

options.label: B
options.text: The group is safe and free from the curse

options.label: C
options.text: The group is doomed

options.label: D

options.text: 500 million times per year

options.text: Historical fiction

title: Why are human bodies asymmetrical? - Leo Q. Wan

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following examples illustrates asymmetry in nature?

options.label: A
options.text: A butterfly with symmetrical patterns on each wing

options.label: B
options.text: A snail species whose shells always coil in the same direction

options.label: C
options.text: A perfectly shaped leaf

options.label: D
options.text: A species of beans that grow equally on both sides of their trellises

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following organs in the human body are examples of asymmetric organs?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart and stomach

options.label: B
options.text: The liver and gallbladder

options.label: C
options.text: The lungs

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition called when all internal organs are flipped, often resulting in a harmless outcome?

options.label: A
options.text: Situs inversus

options.label: B
options.text: Organ asymmetry

options.label: C
options.text: Embryonic reversal

options.label: D
options.text: Anatomical mirroring

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the small pit on the embryo that is lined with tiny hairs called cilia, which play a crucial role in establishing asymmetry?

options.label: A
options.text: The node

options.label: B
options.text: The embryonic pore

options.label: C
options.text: The primitive streak

options.label: D
options.text: The blastocoel

multiple-choice.question: How do the cilia on the node's left-hand rim respond to the fluid flow generated by the synchronized rotation of cilia?

options.label: A
options.text: By changing the direction of rotation

options.label: B
options.text: By activating specific genes on the embryo's left side

options.label: C
options.text: By pushing fluid from the left side of the embryo to the right

options.label: D
options.text: By stopping their rotation

multiple-choice.question: What is the property of molecules that is reflected in asymmetric cells and organisms, where a molecule and its mirror image are not identical?

options.label: A
options.text: Symmetry

options.label: B
options.text: Chirality

options.label: C
options.text: Asymmetry

options.label: D
options.text: Isomerism

options.label: A
options.text: Humans

options.label: B
options.text: Pigs

options.label: C
options.text: Snails

options.label: D
options.text: Mice

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the synchronized rotation of the cilia on the node, which helps establish asymmetry in the embryo?

options.label: A
options.text: The activation of specific genes on the embryo's right side

options.label: B
options.text: The activation of specific genes on the embryo's left side

options.label: C
options.text: The fluid flow from the left side of the embryo to the right

options.label: D
options.text: The fluid flow from the right side of the embryo to the left

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the tube along the center of the embryo that eventually turns into the asymmetric heart through a process of bending and rotation?

options.label: A
options.text: The embryonic tube

options.label: B
options.text: The heart tube

options.label: C
options.text: The cardiac tube

options.label: D
options.text: The primitive heart

options.label: B
options.text: It can be fatal

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the organism

options.label: D
options.text: It results in situs inversus

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The extinction of species during the Ice Age

options.label: C
options.text: The extinction of species due to human activity

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The formation of vast deserts and the elimination of shallow tropical seas

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Migration

options.label: C
options.text: Adaptation

options.label: D
options.text: Evolution

options.label: B
options.text: The extinction of no species

options.label: C
options.text: A change in the Earth's axis

options.label: D
options.text: Changes in sea levels, weather patterns, and ocean currents

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of human activity on the extinction of species?

options.label: B
options.text: Humans have no effect on the extinction of species

options.label: C
options.text: Humans are not contributing to the extinction of species

options.label: D
options.text: Humans are contributing to the extinction of species, but can also work to prevent it

multiple-choice.question: What is the rate of extinction today for many organisms compared to the normal background rate?

options.text: The same as the normal background rate

options.label: B
options.text: Only slightly higher than the normal background rate

options.label: C
options.text: Thousands of times lower than the normal background rate

options.label: D
options.text: Hundreds to thousands of times higher than the normal background rate

multiple-choice.question: What unique ability makes humans capable of driving mass extinctions, but also enables us to prevent them?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to dominate other species

options.label: B
options.text: The ability to migrate to new environments

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to adapt to changes in the environment

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to learn from past extinction events and use knowledge to lessen our effect on other species

title: Holocaust survivor Francine Christophe shares her story

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of sustainable design in building construction?

options.label: A
options.text: To prioritize luxury features over environmental concerns

options.label: B
options.text: To minimize construction costs while compromising building functionality

options.label: C
options.text: To create buildings that are only functional and cost-effective

options.label: D
options.text: To minimize the environmental impact of buildings while maintaining functionality

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of a renewable energy source?

options.label: A
options.text: Fossil fuels, such as coal and natural gas

options.label: B
options.text: Nuclear power, which relies on finite resources

options.label: C
options.text: Solar power, which harnesses energy from the sun

options.label: D
options.text: Biofuels derived from non-renewable sources

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of incorporating energy-efficient systems in sustainable design?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase energy consumption for more power

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce energy consumption, lower costs, and minimize environmental impact

options.label: C
options.text: To create a healthier living space with more natural light

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the lifespan of building components and reduce maintenance

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following materials is an example of a locally sourced material with a low environmental impact?

options.label: A
options.text: Plywood made from tropical hardwoods, contributing to deforestation

options.label: B
options.text: Recycled steel from distant sources, requiring significant transportation

options.label: C
options.text: Reclaimed wood from local sources, reducing waste and transportation emissions

options.label: D
options.text: Cement made from limestone, requiring significant energy for production

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of designing buildings that are adaptable and can be easily modified or repurposed?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased construction costs due to complex design

options.label: B
options.text: Reduced environmental impact through reduced waste and material usage

options.label: C
options.text: Improved occupant health and comfort through flexible layouts

options.label: D
options.text: Increased building lifespan, reduced waste, and lower maintenance costs

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a key principle of sustainable design?

options.label: A
options.text: Using non-renewable energy sources for convenience

options.label: B
options.text: Incorporating energy-efficient systems to reduce energy consumption

options.label: C
options.text: Selecting materials that are locally sourced and have a low environmental impact

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C, as they reduce environmental impact and promote sustainability

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between sustainable design and occupant health and comfort?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no relationship, as sustainability only focuses on the environment

options.label: B
options.text: Sustainable design can improve occupant health and comfort through natural light and ventilation

options.label: C
options.text: Sustainable design can decrease occupant health and comfort due to limited resources

options.label: D
options.text: Sustainable design prioritizes environmental concerns over occupant health and comfort

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of a cost-effective strategy in sustainable design?

options.label: A
options.text: Using high-end materials for luxury features

options.label: B
options.text: Incorporating energy-efficient systems to reduce energy consumption

options.label: C
options.text: Selecting materials that are locally sourced and have a low environmental impact

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C, as they reduce costs and environmental impact

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of using renewable energy sources in sustainable design?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced energy consumption through efficient systems

options.label: B
options.text: Increased energy consumption for more power

options.label: C
options.text: Improved occupant health and comfort through natural light

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced environmental impact through lower greenhouse gas emissions

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following best describes the core objective of sustainable design?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating buildings that are only functional and cost-effective

options.label: B
options.text: Creating buildings that are visually appealing and trendy

options.label: C
options.text: Minimizing the environmental impact of buildings while maintaining functionality

options.label: D
options.text: Balancing aesthetics, functionality, and environmental responsibility for a sustainable future
